Problem:
Consider a system governed by the partial differential equation (PDE) \\(\\frac{\\partial u}{\\partial t} = Lu\\), where \\(L\\) represents a linear differential operator. We explore the effects of applying a Fourier Transform \\(F(u)\\) to the function \\(u(x, t)\\) in terms of spatial variable \\(x\\).

If a Fourier Transform \\(F(u)\\) is applied to \\(u(x, 0)\\) at time t = 0, and then allowed to evolve under the PDE \\(\\frac{\\partial u}{\partial t} = Lu\\) without further intervention, will the transformed state \\(\\hat{u}(k, T)\\) at t = T be equivalent to directly evolving \\(u(x, 0)\\) under the same PDE and then applying \\(F\\)?
Explanation: Under the linear PDE, the Fourier transform of the evolved state \\(\\hat{u}(k, T)\\) will be equivalent to the evolution in the Fourier space of \\(\\hat{u}(k, 0)\\) since the Fourier Transform linearly diagonalizes \\(L\\), assuming \\(L\\) is a translation-invariant operator. Hence, transformations and time evolutions can commute.

causal_map_integration: Applying the Fourier Transform to the initial condition u(x, 0) results in \(\hat{u}(k, 0)\), which, when evolved under the PDE, leads to \(\hat{u}(k, T)\). Directly evolving u(x, 0) under the PDE and then applying the Fourier Transform gives \(F(u(x, T))\). The Fourier Transform of the evolved function u(x, T) equals the evolved Fourier Transform of the initial condition, i.e., \(\hat{u}(k, T) = F(u(x, T))\).
